an10.93:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an10.93:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an10.93:1.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati divā divassa sāvatthiyā nikkhami bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
an10.93:1.2.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.

an10.93:1.4.eng: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,

an10.93:1.6.eng: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,

an10.93:1.8.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
an10.93:1.8.eng: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

an10.93:2.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
an10.93:2.1.eng: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions.

an10.93:2.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatitthiyā paribbājakā saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentā nisinnā honti.
an10.93:2.2.eng: Now at that time, the wanderers of other religions had come together, making an uproar, a colossal racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of low topics.

an10.93:2.3.pli: Addasaṃsu kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
an10.93:2.3.eng: They saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance,

an10.93:2.5.eng: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.

an10.93:2.6.pli: Ayaṃ anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati ārāmaṃ āgacchati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako.
an10.93:2.6.eng: The householder Anāthapiṇḍika, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming into our monastery.

an10.93:2.7.pli: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasanti, ayaṃ tesaṃ aññataro anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati.
an10.93:2.7.eng: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī.

an10.93:2.8.pli: Appasaddakāmā kho pana te āyasmanto appasaddavinītā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino.
an10.93:2.8.eng: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.

an10.93:2.9.pli: Appeva nāma appasaddaṃ parisaṃ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
an10.93:2.9.eng: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”

an10.93:3.1.pli: Atha kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an10.93:3.1.eng: Then those wanderers of other religions fell silent.

an10.93:3.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.93:3.2.eng: Then Anāthapiṇḍika went up to them, and exchanged greetings with those wanderers.

an10.93:3.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:
an10.93:3.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The wanderers said to him,

an10.93:3.4.eng: “Tell us, householder, what is the view of the ascetic Gotama?”

an10.93:3.5.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sabbaṃ diṭṭhiṃ jānāmī”ti.
an10.93:3.5.eng: “Sirs, I don’t know all his views.”

an10.93:4.1.pli: “Iti kira tvaṃ, gahapati, na samaṇassa gotamassa sabbaṃ diṭṭhiṃ jānāsi;
an10.93:4.1.eng: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama,

an10.93:4.2.eng: tell us, what are the views of the mendicants?”

an10.93:4.3.pli: “Bhikkhūnampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, na sabbaṃ diṭṭhiṃ jānāmī”ti.
an10.93:4.3.eng: “Sirs, I don’t know all the mendicants’ views.”

an10.93:5.1.pli: “Iti kira tvaṃ, gahapati, na samaṇassa gotamassa sabbaṃ diṭṭhiṃ jānāsi napi bhikkhūnaṃ sabbaṃ diṭṭhiṃ jānāsi;
an10.93:5.1.eng: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama or of the mendicants,

an10.93:5.2.eng: tell us, householder, what is your view?”

an10.93:5.3.pli: “Etaṃ kho, bhante, amhehi na dukkaraṃ byākātuṃ yaṃdiṭṭhikā mayaṃ.
an10.93:5.3.eng: “Sirs, it’s not hard for me to explain what my views are.

an10.93:5.4.pli: Iṅgha tāva āyasmanto yathāsakāni diṭṭhigatāni byākarontu, pacchāpetaṃ amhehi na dukkaraṃ bhavissati byākātuṃ yaṃdiṭṭhikā mayan”ti.
an10.93:5.4.eng: But please, let the venerables explain their own convictions first. Afterwards it won’t be hard for me to explain my views.”

an10.93:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro paribbājako anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
an10.93:6.1.eng: When he said this, one of the wanderers said to him,

an10.93:6.2.eng: “The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:7.1.pli: Aññataropi kho paribbājako anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:

an10.93:7.2.eng: “The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:8.1.pli: Aññataropi kho paribbājako anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:

an10.93:8.4.eng: “The soul and the body are one and the same …” …

an10.93:8.5.eng: “The soul is one thing, the body another …” …

an10.93:8.6.eng: “A realized one still exists after death …” …

an10.93:8.7.eng: “A realized one no longer exists after death …” …

an10.93:8.8.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …
an10.93:8.8.eng: “A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …” …

an10.93:8.9.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—
an10.93:8.9.eng: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati te paribbājake etadavoca:
an10.93:9.1.eng: When this was said, Anāthapiṇḍika said this,

an10.93:9.2.eng: “Sirs, regarding the venerable who said this:

an10.93:9.3.eng: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:9.5.pli: imassa ayamāyasmato diṭṭhi attano vā ayonisomanasikārahetu uppannā paratoghosapaccayā vā.
an10.93:9.5.eng: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.

an10.93:9.6.pli: Sā kho panesā diṭṭhi bhūtā saṅkhatā cetayitā paṭiccasamuppannā.
an10.93:9.6.eng: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.

an10.93:9.7.pli: Yaṃ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:9.7.eng: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:9.9.pli: Yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato.
an10.93:9.9.eng: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.

an10.93:10.1.eng: Regarding the venerable who said this:

an10.93:10.2.eng: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:10.4.pli: imassāpi ayamāyasmato diṭṭhi attano vā ayonisomanasikārahetu uppannā paratoghosapaccayā vā.
an10.93:10.4.eng: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.

an10.93:10.5.pli: Sā kho panesā diṭṭhi bhūtā saṅkhatā cetayitā paṭiccasamuppannā.
an10.93:10.5.eng: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.

an10.93:10.6.pli: Yaṃ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:10.6.eng: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:10.8.pli: Yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato.
an10.93:10.8.eng: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.

an10.93:11.1.eng: Regarding the venerable who said this:

an10.93:11.4.eng: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same …’ …

an10.93:11.5.eng: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …

an10.93:11.6.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …

an10.93:11.7.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.93:11.8.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …
an10.93:11.8.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.93:11.9.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti—
an10.93:11.9.eng: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.

an10.93:11.11.pli: imassāpi ayamāyasmato diṭṭhi attano vā ayonisomanasikārahetu uppannā paratoghosapaccayā vā.
an10.93:11.11.eng: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.

an10.93:11.12.pli: Sā kho panesā diṭṭhi bhūtā saṅkhatā cetayitā paṭiccasamuppannā.
an10.93:11.12.eng: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.

an10.93:11.13.pli: Yaṃ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:11.13.eng: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:11.15.pli: Yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato”ti.
an10.93:11.15.eng: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.”

an10.93:12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte te paribbājakā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavocuṃ:
an10.93:12.1.eng: When he said this the wanderers said to him,

an10.93:12.2.pli: “byākatāni kho, gahapati, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakāni diṭṭhigatāni.
an10.93:12.2.eng: “Householder, we’ve each explained our own convictions.

an10.93:12.3.eng: Tell us, householder, what is your view?”

an10.93:12.4.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhante, kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:12.4.eng: “Sirs, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:12.6.pli: ‘Yaṃ dukkhaṃ taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—
an10.93:12.6.eng: And what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.

an10.93:13.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho, gahapati, kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:13.1.eng: “Householder, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:13.3.pli: Yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadeva tvaṃ, gahapati, allīno, tadeva tvaṃ, gahapati, ajjhupagato”ti.
an10.93:13.3.eng: What you cling to and hold to is just suffering.”

an10.93:14.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhante, kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ cetayitaṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ tadaniccaṃ.
an10.93:14.1.eng: “Sirs, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.

an10.93:14.3.pli: ‘Yaṃ dukkhaṃ taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, nameso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ.
an10.93:14.3.eng: And I’ve truly seen clearly with right wisdom that what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, it’s not my self.

an10.93:14.4.pli: Tassa ca uttari nissaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
an10.93:14.4.eng: And I truly understand the escape beyond that.”

an10.93:15.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte te paribbājakā tuṇhībhūtā maṅkubhūtā pattakkhandhā adhomukhā pajjhāyantā appaṭibhānā nisīdiṃsu.
an10.93:15.1.eng: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

an10.93:15.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati te paribbājake tuṇhībhūte maṅkubhūte pattakkhandhe adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yāvatako ahosi tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
an10.93:15.2.eng: Seeing this, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.

an10.93:15.4.pli: Evaṃ kho te, gahapati, moghapurisā kālena kālaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetabbā”ti.
an10.93:15.4.eng: That’s how you should legitimately and completely refute those futile men from time to time.”

an10.93:16.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
an10.93:16.1.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the householder Anāthapiṇḍika with a Dhamma talk,

an10.93:16.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an10.93:16.2.eng: after which Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.

an10.93:17.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante anāthapiṇḍike gahapatimhi bhikkhū āmantesi:
an10.93:17.1.eng: Then, not long after Anāthapiṇḍika had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an10.93:17.2.pli: “yopi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vassasatupasampanno imasmiṃ dhammavinaye, sopi evamevaṃ aññatitthiye paribbājake sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggaṇheyya yathā taṃ anāthapiṇḍikena gahapatinā niggahitā”ti.
an10.93:17.2.eng: “Mendicants, even a mendicant who has ordained for a hundred years in this teaching and training would legitimately and completely refute those wanderers of other religions just as the householder Anāthapiṇḍika did.”

an10.94:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre.
an10.94:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond.

an10.94:1.2.pli: Atha kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati divā divassa campāya nikkhami bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
an10.94:1.2.eng: Then the householder Vajjiyamāhita left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.

an10.94:1.4.eng: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,

an10.94:1.6.eng: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,

an10.94:1.8.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
an10.94:1.8.eng: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

an10.94:2.1.pli: Atha kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
an10.94:2.1.eng: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions.

an10.94:2.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentā nisinnā honti.
an10.94:2.2.eng: Now at that time, the wanderers of other religions had come together, making an uproar, a colossal racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of low topics.

an10.94:3.1.pli: Addasaṃsu kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā vajjiyamāhitaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ. Disvāna aññamaññaṃ saṇṭhāpesuṃ:
an10.94:3.1.eng: They saw Vajjiyamāhita coming off in the distance, and stopped each other, saying,

an10.94:3.2.eng: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.

an10.94:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ vajjiyamāhito gahapati āgacchati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako.
an10.94:3.3.eng: The householder Vajjiyamāhita, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming into our monastery.

an10.94:3.4.pli: Yāvatā kho pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā campāyaṃ paṭivasanti, ayaṃ tesaṃ aññataro vajjiyamāhito gahapati.
an10.94:3.4.eng: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Campā.

an10.94:3.5.pli: Appasaddakāmā kho pana te āyasmanto appasaddavinītā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādino.
an10.94:3.5.eng: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.

an10.94:3.6.pli: Appeva nāma appasaddaṃ parisaṃ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
an10.94:3.6.eng: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”

an10.94:4.1.pli: Atha kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an10.94:4.1.eng: Then those wanderers of other religions fell silent.

an10.94:4.2.pli: Atha kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati yena te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.94:4.2.eng: Then Vajjiyamāhita went up to them, and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

an10.94:4.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho vajjiyamāhitaṃ gahapatiṃ te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:
an10.94:4.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The wanderers said to him:

an10.94:4.4.pli: “saccaṃ kira, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī”ti?
an10.94:4.4.eng: “Is it really true, householder? Does the ascetic Gotama criticize all forms of mortification? Does he categorically condemn and denounce those fervent mortifiers who live rough?”

an10.94:4.5.pli: “Na kho, bhante, bhagavā sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati napi sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadati.
an10.94:4.5.eng: “No, sirs, the Buddha does not criticize all forms of mortification. Nor does he categorically condemn and denounce those fervent mortifiers who live rough.

an10.94:4.6.pli: Gārayhaṃ kho, bhante, bhagavā garahati, pasaṃsitabbaṃ pasaṃsati.
an10.94:4.6.eng: The Buddha criticizes where it is due, and praises where it is due.

an10.94:4.7.pli: Gārayhaṃ kho pana, bhante, bhagavā garahanto pasaṃsitabbaṃ pasaṃsanto vibhajjavādo bhagavā.
an10.94:4.7.eng: In doing so he is one who speaks after analyzing the question,

an10.94:4.8.eng: and is not one-sided on this point.”

an10.94:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro paribbājako vajjiyamāhitaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
an10.94:5.1.eng: When he said this, one of the wanderers said to him,

an10.94:5.2.pli: “āgamehi tvaṃ, gahapati, yassa tvaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, samaṇo gotamo venayiko appaññattiko”ti?
an10.94:5.2.eng: “Hold on, householder! That ascetic Gotama who you praise is an exterminator who refrains from making statements.”

an10.94:5.3.eng: “On this point, also, I reasonably respond to the venerables.

an10.94:5.4.eng: The Buddha has stated ‘This is skillful’ and

an10.94:5.6.pli: Iti kusalākusalaṃ bhagavā paññāpayamāno sapaññattiko bhagavā;
an10.94:5.6.eng: So when it comes to what is skillful and unskillful the Buddha makes a statement.

an10.94:5.7.eng: He is not an exterminator who refrains from making statements.”

an10.94:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte te paribbājakā tuṇhībhūtā maṅkubhūtā pattakkhandhā adhomukhā pajjhāyantā appaṭibhānā nisīdiṃsu.
an10.94:6.1.eng: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

an10.94:6.2.pli: Atha kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati te paribbājake tuṇhībhūte maṅkubhūte pattakkhandhe adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an10.94:6.2.eng: Seeing this, Vajjiyamāhita got up from his seat. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

an10.94:6.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati yāvatako ahosi tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
an10.94:6.3.eng: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.

an10.94:7.2.pli: Evaṃ kho te, gahapati, moghapurisā kālena kālaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetabbā.
an10.94:7.2.eng: That’s how you should legitimately and completely refute those futile men from time to time.

an10.94:7.3.pli: Nāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ tapaṃ tapitabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.3.eng: Householder, I don’t say that all mortifications should be undergone.

an10.94:7.4.pli: na ca panāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ tapaṃ na tapitabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.4.eng: But I don’t say that no mortifications should be undergone.

an10.94:7.5.pli: nāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ samādānaṃ samāditabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.5.eng: I don’t say that all observances should be undertaken.

an10.94:7.6.pli: na panāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ samādānaṃ na samāditabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.6.eng: But I don’t say that no observances should be undertaken.

an10.94:7.7.pli: nāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ padhānaṃ padahitabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.7.eng: I don’t say that all efforts should be tried.

an10.94:7.8.pli: na panāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbaṃ padhānaṃ na padahitabbanti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.8.eng: But I don’t say that no efforts should be tried.

an10.94:7.9.pli: nāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbo paṭinissaggo paṭinissajjitabboti vadāmi.
an10.94:7.9.eng: I don’t say that everything should be given up.

an10.94:7.10.pli: Na panāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbo paṭinissaggo na paṭinissajjitabboti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.10.eng: But I don’t say that nothing should be given up.

an10.94:7.11.pli: nāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbā vimutti vimuccitabbāti vadāmi;
an10.94:7.11.eng: I don’t say that you should be liberated with all kinds of freedom.

an10.94:7.12.pli: na panāhaṃ, gahapati, sabbā vimutti na vimuccitabbāti vadāmi.
an10.94:7.12.eng: But I don’t say that you should not be liberated with any kind of freedom.

an10.94:8.1.pli: Yañhi, gahapati, tapaṃ tapato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ tapaṃ na tapitabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:8.1.eng: When undergoing certain mortifications, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t undergo those mortifications.

an10.94:8.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, gahapati, tapaṃ tapato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ tapaṃ tapitabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:8.2.eng: When undergoing certain mortifications, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should undergo those mortifications.

an10.94:9.1.pli: Yañhi, gahapati, samādānaṃ samādiyato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ samādānaṃ na samāditabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:9.1.eng: When undertaking certain observances, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t undertake those observances.

an10.94:9.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, gahapati, samādānaṃ samādiyato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ samādānaṃ samāditabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:9.2.eng: When undertaking certain observances, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should undertake those observances.

an10.94:10.1.pli: Yañhi, gahapati, padhānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ padhānaṃ na padahitabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:10.1.eng: When trying certain efforts, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t try those efforts.

an10.94:10.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, gahapati, padhānaṃ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ padhānaṃ padahitabbanti vadāmi.
an10.94:10.2.eng: When trying certain efforts, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should try those efforts.

an10.94:11.1.pli: Yañhi, gahapati, paṭinissaggaṃ paṭinissajjato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpo paṭinissaggo na paṭinissajjitabboti vadāmi.
an10.94:11.1.eng: When giving up certain things, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t give up those things.

an10.94:11.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, gahapati, paṭinissaggaṃ paṭinissajjato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpo paṭinissaggo paṭinissajjitabboti vadāmi.
an10.94:11.2.eng: When giving up certain things, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should give up those things.

an10.94:12.1.pli: Yañhi, gahapati, vimuttiṃ vimuccato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpā vimutti na vimuccitabbāti vadāmi.
an10.94:12.1.eng: When being liberated with certain kinds of freedom, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t be liberated with those kinds of freedom.

an10.94:12.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, gahapati, vimuttiṃ vimuccato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpā vimutti vimuccitabbāti vadāmī”ti.
an10.94:12.2.eng: When being liberated with certain kinds of freedom, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should be liberated with those kinds of freedom.”

an10.94:13.1.pli: Atha kho vajjiyamāhito gahapati bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an10.94:13.1.eng: After Vajjiyamāhita had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.

an10.94:14.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante vajjiyamāhite gahapatimhi bhikkhū āmantesi:
an10.94:14.1.eng: Then, not long after Vajjiyamāhita had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an10.94:14.2.pli: “yopi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dīgharattaṃ apparajakkho imasmiṃ dhammavinaye, sopi evamevaṃ aññatitthiye paribbājake sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggaṇheyya yathā taṃ vajjiyamāhitena gahapatinā niggahitā”ti.
an10.94:14.2.eng: “Mendicants, even a mendicant who for a long time has had little dust in their eye in this teaching and training would legitimately and completely refute those wanderers of other religions just as the householder Vajjiyamāhita did.”

an10.95:1.1.pli: Atha kho uttiyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an10.95:1.1.eng: Then the wanderer Uttiya went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an10.95:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uttiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.95:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

an10.95:1.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti?
an10.95:1.3.eng: “Worthy Gotama, is this right: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.95:1.4.eng: “This has not been declared by me, Uttiya.”

an10.95:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti?
an10.95:2.1.eng: “Then is this right: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.95:2.2.eng: “This has not been declared by me, Uttiya.”

an10.95:3.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, antavā loko …pe…
an10.95:3.1.eng: “Then is this right: ‘The cosmos is finite …’ …

an10.95:3.3.eng: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing …’ …

an10.95:3.4.eng: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …

an10.95:3.5.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …

an10.95:3.6.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.95:3.7.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …
an10.95:3.7.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …

an10.95:3.8.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti?
an10.95:3.8.eng: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”

an10.95:3.9.eng: “This has not been declared by me, Uttiya.”

an10.95:3.10.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’”ti.

an10.95:4.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘abyākataṃ kho etaṃ, uttiya, mayā—
an10.95:4.1.eng: “When asked about all these points, worthy Gotama says that they have not been declared by him.

an10.95:4.2.pli: sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.95:5.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an10.95:5.2.pli: ‘etampi kho, uttiya, abyākataṃ mayā asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.95:6.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, antavā loko …pe…

an10.95:6.7.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …

an10.95:6.8.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an10.95:6.10.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti vadesi.

an10.95:6.11.eng: So what then has been declared by Mister Gotama?”

an10.95:7.1.pli: “Abhiññāya kho ahaṃ, uttiya, sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ desemi sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
an10.95:7.1.eng: “Uttiya, I teach my disciples from my own insight in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.”

an10.95:8.1.pli: “Yaṃ panetaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo abhiññāya sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ desesi sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, sabbo vā tena loko nīyati upaḍḍho vā tibhāgo vā”ti?
an10.95:8.1.eng: “But when the worthy Gotama teaches in this way, is the whole world saved, or half, or a third?”

an10.95:8.2.eng: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.

an10.95:9.2.pli: “mā hevaṃ kho uttiyo paribbājako pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ paṭilabhi:
an10.95:9.2.eng: “The wanderer Uttiya must not get the harmful misconception:

an10.95:9.3.pli: ‘sabbasāmukkaṃsikaṃ vata me samaṇo gotamo pañhaṃ puṭṭho saṃsādeti, no vissajjeti, na nūna visahatī’ti.
an10.95:9.3.eng: ‘When the ascetic Gotama was asked this all-important question he falters without answering. He just can’t do it!’

an10.95:9.4.pli: Tadassa uttiyassa paribbājakassa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an10.95:9.4.eng: That would be for his lasting harm and suffering.”

an10.95:10.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando uttiyaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
an10.95:10.1.eng: Then Ānanda said to the wanderer Uttiya,

an10.95:10.2.eng: “Well then, Reverend Uttiya, I shall give you a simile.

an10.95:10.3.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
an10.95:10.3.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

an10.95:10.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso uttiya, rañño paccantimaṃ nagaraṃ daḷhuddhāpaṃ daḷhapākāratoraṇaṃ ekadvāraṃ.
an10.95:10.4.eng: Suppose there was a king’s frontier citadel with fortified embankments, ramparts, and arches, and a single gate.

an10.95:10.5.pli: Tatrassa dovāriko paṇḍito byatto medhāvī aññātānaṃ nivāretā ñātānaṃ pavesetā.
an10.95:10.5.eng: And it has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and clever. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.

an10.95:10.6.pli: So tassa nagarassa samantā anupariyāyapathaṃ anukkamati. Anupariyāyapathaṃ anukkamamāno na passeyya pākārasandhiṃ vā pākāravivaraṃ vā, antamaso biḷāranikkhamanamattampi.
an10.95:10.6.eng: As he walks around the patrol path, he doesn’t see a hole or cleft in the wall, not even one big enough for a cat to slip out.

an10.95:10.7.pli: No ca khvassa evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti: ‘ettakā pāṇā imaṃ nagaraṃ pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā’ti.
an10.95:10.7.eng: He doesn’t know how many creatures enter or leave the citadel.

an10.95:10.8.pli: Atha khvassa evamettha hoti: ‘ye kho keci oḷārikā pāṇā imaṃ nagaraṃ pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā, sabbe te iminā dvārena pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā’ti.
an10.95:10.8.eng: But he does know that whatever sizable creatures enter or leave the citadel, all of them do so via this gate.

an10.95:11.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso uttiya, na tathāgatassa evaṃ ussukkaṃ hoti: ‘sabbo vā tena loko nīyati, upaḍḍho vā, tibhāgo vā’ti.
an10.95:11.1.eng: In the same way, it’s not the Realized One’s concern whether the whole world is saved by this, or half, or a third.

an10.95:11.2.pli: Atha kho evamettha tathāgatassa hoti: ‘ye kho keci lokamhā nīyiṃsu vā nīyanti vā nīyissanti vā, sabbe te pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā.
an10.95:11.2.eng: But the Realized One knows that whoever is saved from the world—whether in the past, the future, or the present—all have given up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. They have firmly established their mind in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. And they have truly developed the seven awakening factors.

an10.95:11.3.pli: Evamete lokamhā nīyiṃsu vā nīyanti vā nīyissanti vā’ti.
an10.95:11.3.eng: That’s how they’re saved from the world, in the past, future, or present.

an10.95:11.4.pli: Yadeva kho tvaṃ, āvuso uttiya, bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi tadevetaṃ pañhaṃ bhagavantaṃ aññena pariyāyena apucchi.
an10.95:11.4.eng: Uttiya, you were just asking the Buddha the same question as before in a different way.

an10.95:11.5.pli: Tasmā te taṃ bhagavā na byākāsī”ti.
